awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Physical Properties Measurement System for Research, Education, and Outreach
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Division of Materials Research supports the acquisition of a Quantum Design Physical Properties Measurement System (PPMS) at Western Michigan University. The instrument provides a powerful new capability for measurements of the electrical, magnetic, thermal, and optical properties of a wide variety of materials under different conditions.  Materials are being studied which may enable the following: improved electrical transmission and energy storage, quantum computing, molecular electronics, more efficient refrigeration, printed electronics, and new lower cost methods of solar energy conversion. In addition to benefiting four departments in science and engineering at Western Michigan University, the instrument will serve as a local resource for a research hub including five nearby colleges and universities. Students at all these institutions will gain valuable experience using a state-of-the-art instrument for their research and education. Community outreach will engage local high school students in long-term research projects, helping spread the excitement of science to the next generation. 

 
With this award from the Division of Materials Research, researchers at Western Michigan University will acquire a system to enable measurements of resistivity, carrier concentration, specific heat, optical properties, and magnetization as a function of temperature (0.05-400K) and magnetic field (0-14T). One major use will be for studies of high temperature and exotic superconductivity.  Studies will explore superconductivity in doped lead chalcogenides, Bi based topological superconductors, and determine how to improve critical current densities in commercial high temperature superconducting wires using vortex pinning. Additional research projects include characterizing the properties of doped lead perovskite semiconductors, exploring the interplay of structure and composition on the magnetocaloric effect in Ni-Mn Heusler alloys, measuring the relation between the magnetic and structural properties of molecular magnets, determining optical properties of nitrogen vacancy centers in diamond, and studying the electrical and magnetic properties of metallic inks for printed electronics. These research projects will benefit society by advancing fundamental understanding of technologically important phenomena. This instrument will significantly improve the education and training for future scientists, engineers, and teachers, including those from underrepresented groups. The project includes local collaborations for research and education for undergraduates and faculty from five nearby universities. The resulting regional research community will benefit smaller institutions where faculty have limited instrumentation and few or no institutional colleagues in their research area. Outreach activities will also provide research opportunities for talented high school students, including populations traditionally underrepresented in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award was for the acquisition of a cryogen-free Quantum Design Physical Property Measurement System (PPMS), which is a multipurpose tool for characterizing materials as a function of temperature (0.05-400 K) and magnetic field (0-14 T). Resistivity, carrier concentration, specific heat, and magnetization as a function of magnetic field and temperature are fundamental properties the PPMS can measure.  These properties are essential to understanding materials of interest in condensed matter physics, chemistry, materials science, and engineering. Acquisition of this instrument benefits many areas of fundamental and applied research at the institutions involved. The PPMS provides the opportunity to train graduate and undergraduate students on a state-of-the-art instrument which allows them to work on important questions of current interest.  The instrument is also used in outreach activities with local high school students who carry out long term projects with faculty at the university. 

Intellectual Merit: The PPMS has enabled studies of vortex behavior in high-temperature superconductors, helped understand superconducting critical currents in commercial high temperature superconducting wires, provided information on the behavior of non-centrosymmetric superconductors, facilitated the understanding of the magnetocaloric effect in Ni-Mn Heusler alloys, and helped determine the relation of magnetic and structural properties of molecular magnets.  The PPMS should remain operational for many years, allowing for a large number of measurements in the future.  PPMS data have been used in four Ph. D. theses, two published papers (with three more in preparation), as well as numerous talks and poster presentations.  The PPMS is also being used to characterize printed inks as part of a Department of Energy Advanced Manufacturing Office project. The goal of this project is to bring advanced printing methods to lithium battery manufacture, to allow for lower cost and more rapid charging.

Broader Impact: The instrument received through this grant provides science and engineering education opportunities for many different students, including graduate students carrying out work for their Ph. D. theses, undergraduates doing independent research and senior theses, and high school students carrying out long term projects.  Faculty from Physics, Chemistry, and Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering from Western Michigan University have carried out experiments with the instrument, and faculty from several local universities have used the instrument for research and education.  Four Ph. D. theses using the data from the instrument have been successfully defended, and four graduate students are currently using the instrument for their research.  Several of the undergraduates who have carried out measurements have been accepted to Ph.D. programs in physics or engineering.   The instrument has been used as part of the undergraduate Physics 4660 Advanced Laboratory at Western Michigan University for a lab entitled "Broken Symmetry".  Eight high school students, most from the Kalamazoo Area Math and Science Center (a regional magnet school for the sciences) have carried out long term experiments using the instrument. Two of these students won their high school science fairs (in 2019 and 2020) and were invited to the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair.
